summary: this study explores the role of socio-cognitive factors that affect the decision of wearing a pollution mask in young educated people. this is done by selecting a sample of college students in urban china, a country that has seen air quality as one of the major challenges in the last decades. this study has the potential to inform policies aimed at changing suboptimal behavioural attitudes by identifying triggers for change. it could serve in improving tailoring of health promotion messages aimed at nudging healthy behaviour.
